stem: Click to highlight the findings that require immediate notification of the healthcare provider.
passage: The nurse is caring for a 72-year-old client admitted for management of atrial fibrillation and seizure disorder. The client is prescribed digoxin 0.125 mg daily and phenytoin 100 mg three times daily. Upon assessment, the nurse notes [apical pulse of 52 bpm], [slurred speech], [nystagmus], [serum phenytoin level of 28 mcg/mL], [serum digoxin level of 2.5 ng/mL], and [BP 90/60 mmHg]. The client also reports [blurred vision] and [nausea]. The ECG shows [prolonged PR interval].

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 S: Mr. Johnson, 72 y.o. admitted for A-fib and seizure management. O: A&Ox3, but increasingly lethargic. Complains of nausea and blurred vision. A: Possible digoxin and phenytoin toxicity. Recent lab results pending. R: Requesting urgent evaluation due to bradycardia (HR 52), hypotension (BP 90/60), new-onset slurred speech, and nystagmus. ECG shows prolonged PR interval. Phenytoin level 28 mcg/mL, Digoxin level 2.5 ng/mL. Recommend holding both medications pending physician orders and further investigation. Monitor vital signs closely and assess for further neurological changes. Will update provider with any changes in condition. 
07:15 Notified Dr. Smith. Awaiting orders.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Lethargic, appears weak.
Neuro: A&Ox3 but exhibits slurred speech and horizontal nystagmus. Reflexes 2+ bilaterally. No motor deficits noted. 
Cardio: Apical pulse 52, irregular rhythm. No murmurs auscultated.
Resp: Breath sounds clear bilaterally. 
GI: Complains of nausea. Abdomen soft, non-tender. 
Vision: Reports blurred vision.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Digoxin 0.125 mg PO daily
  • Phenytoin 100 mg PO TID
  • Monitor vital signs Q4H
  • Seizure precautions
  • Fall risk precautions

rationale.correct: The client exhibits signs and symptoms of both digoxin and phenytoin toxicity, requiring immediate notification of the healthcare provider. Bradycardia, hypotension, slurred speech, nystagmus, elevated serum drug levels, blurred vision, nausea, and a prolonged PR interval are all concerning findings that warrant prompt intervention.
rationale.incorrect: While some findings may be related to the client's underlying conditions, the combination of symptoms and lab results strongly suggests drug toxicity. Delaying notification could lead to serious complications.

answerBreakdown.label: apical pulse of 52 bpm
answerBreakdown.content: Bradycardia is a common sign of digoxin toxicity. Digoxin inhibits the Na+/K+-ATPase pump, leading to increased intracellular sodium and decreased intracellular potassium, which can affect the heart's electrical activity and slow the heart rate.

answerBreakdown.label: slurred speech
answerBreakdown.content: Slurred speech is a neurological sign associated with phenytoin toxicity. High levels of phenytoin can impair neuronal function, leading to speech difficulties.

answerBreakdown.label: nystagmus
answerBreakdown.content: Nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) is another neurological sign of phenytoin toxicity, indicating cerebellar dysfunction due to elevated drug levels.

answerBreakdown.label: serum phenytoin level of 28 mcg/mL
answerBreakdown.content: A phenytoin level of 28 mcg/mL is above the therapeutic range (10-20 mcg/mL), indicating toxicity. Elevated levels increase the risk of neurological side effects.

answerBreakdown.label: serum digoxin level of 2.5 ng/mL
answerBreakdown.content: A digoxin level of 2.5 ng/mL is above the therapeutic range (0.5-2.0 ng/mL), indicating toxicity. High levels can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other adverse effects.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 90/60 mmHg
answerBreakdown.content: Hypotension can be a sign of digoxin toxicity, as digoxin can affect cardiac contractility and vascular tone.

answerBreakdown.label: blurred vision
answerBreakdown.content: Blurred vision is a visual disturbance associated with both digoxin and phenytoin toxicity. Digoxin can affect the retinal function, while phenytoin can cause optic nerve or visual cortex dysfunction.

answerBreakdown.label: nausea
answerBreakdown.content: Nausea is a common gastrointestinal symptom of digoxin toxicity. Digoxin can stimulate the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the brain, leading to nausea and vomiting.

answerBreakdown.label: prolonged PR interval
answerBreakdown.content: A prolonged PR interval on the ECG indicates slowed AV conduction, a common finding in digoxin toxicity. Digoxin increases vagal tone, which can slow conduction through the AV node.

clinicalPearls: Always monitor serum drug levels for clients on digoxin and phenytoin, especially with changes in renal function or concurrent medications.
Educate clients about the signs and symptoms of drug toxicity and when to seek medical attention.
Consider drug interactions when prescribing digoxin and phenytoin, as some medications can increase or decrease their serum levels.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing on individual symptoms in isolation rather than recognizing the overall pattern of digoxin and phenytoin toxicity.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider the client's medication history, lab results, and the constellation of symptoms to identify the underlying cause.

mnemonic.title: DIG TOX
mnemonic.expansion: Dizziness, Irregular pulse, GI upset (nausea/vomiting), Tachycardia or bradycardia, Optic disturbances (blurred vision), Xantopsia (yellow vision)
